TextEquiv.Unicode: The studio was ﬁlled with the rich odour of roses, and when the light summer wind stirred amidst the trees of the garden, there came through the open
door the heavy scent of the lilac, or the more delicate perfume of the pink-ﬂowering them.
From the comer of the divan of Persian saddle-bags on which he was lying, smoking, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton
could just catch the gleam of the honey-sweet and honey-coloured blossoms of a labumum, whose tremulous branches seemed hardly able to bear the burden
of a beauty so ﬂamelike as theils; and now and then the fantastic shadows of birds in ﬂight ﬂjtted across the long tussore-silk curtains that were sketched in
front of the huge window, producing a kind of momentary Japanese effect, and making him think of those pal1id,jade-faced painters of Tokyo who, thmugh the
medium of an art that is necessarily immobile, seek to convey the sense of swiﬁness and motion. The sullen murmur of the bees shoulderlng their way through
the long unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence round the dusty gilt hams of the straggling woodbine, seemed to make the stillness more
oppressive. The dim roar of London was like the bourdon note of a distant organ
In the centre of the room, clamped to an upright easel, stood the ﬁlll-le11g1h portrait of a young man of extraordjnmy personal beauty, and in front of it,
some little distance away, was sitting the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance some years ago caused, at the time, such public
excitement and gave rise ta so many slrauge conjectures.
As the painter looked at the gracious and camely form he had so sldlfully minored in his art, a smile of pleasure passed across his face, and seemed
about to linger there. But he suddenly started up, and closing his eyes, placed his ﬁngers upon the lids, as though he sought to imprison within his brain some
cmious dream from which he feared he might awake.
"It is your best work, Basil, the best thing you have ever dune," said Lord Henry languidly. "You must certainly send it next year ta the Gmsvenor. The
Academy is too large and too vulgar. Whenever I have gone there, there have been either so many people that I have not been able ta see the pictures, which
was dreadﬁﬂ, or so many pictures that I have not been able to see the people, which was worse. The Grcsvenor is really the only place."
